title: Review | 'Dirty Dancing' falls short
text:
Review | 'Dirty Dancing' falls short Elizabeth Kramer , @arts_bureau 2:58 p.m. EDT October 14, 2015 Gillian Abbott (Baby) and Christopher Tierney (Johnny) in the North American tour of "Dirty Dancing – The Classic Story on Stage." (Photo: Courtesy PNC Broadway in Louisville.) 5 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The movie from the 1980s that looks back at a 1963 summer that proved a coming-of-age time for Baby came to Louisville Tuesday in the form of a theater piece. 
Even before the storytelling began on stage, audience members were cheering for “Dirty Dancing — The Classic Story on Stage,” part of PNC Broadway in Louisville’s season. 
The crowd was primed for the show in part due to the enduring popularity of the 1987 movie and its soundtrack of 1960s songs, including “Do You Love Me?," “Hey! Baby” and “In the Still of the Night,” mixed with hits “(I've Had) The Time of My Life” and “Hungry Eyes.” Some in the crowd even sang along. 
It didn’t seem to matter that Eleanor Bergstein’s stage adaptation of her screenplay, which had little resemblance to a musical, had quick scenes that ripped through the rich and promising story of the earnest and idealistic Baby (Gillian Abbott) and her family’s stay at Kellerman’s summer resort. 
There, she finds Johnny (Christopher Tierney), her first love among the dancers. 
Also among them is Penny (Jenny Winton), who finds she’s pregnant from an Ivy League student she believed loved her. Baby’s determination to help places her and Penny in a perilous situation that Baby’s father helps rectify — only to lose trust in his daughter. 
This staged version did include some contrived additions that tried to place the story's era, including Baby giving the audience a brief history lesson at the play's start and scenes with various characters talking about the civil rights movement. Very little of it felt grounded in the story. Parsons Dance promises 'a roller coaster ride' 
Given the furious pace this staged version took, the actors didn’t have much time to develop their characters. 
But Abbott as Baby did bring an honesty to her role, and Tierney gave strong street credibility to his portrayal of Johnny. It didn’t hurt that he also oozed with sex appeal. Luckily, that didn’t overshadow his character’s tender moments. Still, there seemed to be very little chemistry between the two. 
However, the love between Baby and her father, Dr. Jacke Houseman (Mark Elliot Wilson) was palpable, warm and steady. Their connection came through clearly when Baby asked for $250 without giving her father a reason and later when she admitted to having stayed at Johnny’s overnight. 
The highlight of this show was the dancing, particularly with Johnny and Penny portrayed by Tierney, who has danced with Chicago’s Hubbard Street Dance as well as ballet companies, and Joffrey Ballet dancer Winton. 
The moves portrayed both the sensual as well as sweet emotions. Tierney’s scenes rehearsing and teaching Baby, in particular, conveyed the hard work and drive this level of dancing requires. With a lot of choreography packed into short spurts of time throughout the show, sometimes the dancing, particularly the fast-paced partnering, felt a bit too frenzied. 
There wasn’t much live singing as compared to most musicals, save for several numbers by a handful of singers backed by a tight live band (Many songs that worked as backdrops for the dance numbers were recordings.). Among them, Jennlee Shallow proved impressive in several numbers as did Doug Carpenter singing “In the Still of the Night.” The unfortunate part of these performances was the sound problems where the band’s playing overshadowed the singers’ voices. 
Christopher Tierney (Johnny) and Jenny Winton (Penny) in the North American tour of "Dirty Dancing – The Classic Story on Stage." (Photo: Photo by Matthew Murphy.) 
While the movie’s imprint was strong throughout the production, the set, designed by Stephen Brimson Lewis, and the video and projections, designed by Jon Driscoll, constituted an intense visual link to film. 
The digital projections established scenes at the resort and in fields, forests and, yes, the lake. That scene where Baby is finally able to perform a lift with Johnny while both are in the lake made one of the most appealing scenes using digital technology. But while it evoked oohs and awes, it frequently hindered intimate moments, often overwhelmed the production and sometimes created an irritating glow that distracted from the actors telling of the story. Fall theater season tackles modern issues 
“Dirty Dancing — The Classic Story on Stage,” by Eleanor Bergstein runs through Sunday at the Kentucky Center as part of the Broadway in Louisville series. For more information, call (502) 844-7777 or visit louisville.broadway.com or www.kentuckycenter.org .
